comments.body: please keep line length pep 8 compliant

Well, de PEP8 line-length was disabled from the checks. 80 columns by today's standards is no longer relevant and IIRC discussions wrt. this were not as strict. Besides the file is full of lines over the 80 column limit, I don't think this is a real concern. is it ?

    [dag@moria modules]$ awk '{ print length }' cloud/vmware/vmware_guest.py | sort | uniq -c | sort -n -k2 | tail
      4 114
      4 115
      2 116
      3 117
      1 118
      1 119
      1 120
      2 133
      1 142
      1 172
I consider folding to 80 columns a bug
IMHO everybody should aim for PEP8 compliance unless it has some very negative impact like creating new variables only to be able to fit into the 80 chars limit.
pycharm reports 120 chars not 80

comments.body: What if 'resource_pool' is not defined?

We are not adding a resource pool.

The select_resource_pool_by_host() is broken. Why are we looking for the first resource_pool of the first host in the cluster (or the esxi_hostname) and using that one ? It results in things like ##22706 or #24548

I see. However, if I don't specify `resource_pool` in my playbook I end up with a `null` value for `resource_pool` and the message:
` "msg": "A specified parameter was not correct: spec.location.pool"`.

That is weird, because the check `if self.params['resource_pool']` should return None, which is considered False by python. We do this because we would like an empty string to also fail. So we don't set `relospec.pool`. That's the intent. Can you try to disable both lines and see if it would work then ? Maybe VMware's error messages are playing up on us again (they really are not very helpful in a lot of cases).

Just to note, this also fixes an error I have had previously when passing a blank string to resource_pool (from a Tower Survey variable).  Previously I would have to resort to completely removing the entry if blank.
`resource_pool: "{{ vCenterResourcePool|default(omit, True) }}"`
what is this r ?

That's a raw string, it's not strictly necessary here, but we want tostandardize this.
This is still open for discussion BTW  but in this context it shouldn't really matter.
line is too long

It is not too long, we have CI for checking this.
The official line-length for Ansible code is 160 characters.

comments.body: Datacenter is required for `FindByInventoryPath`. Without datacenter API, fails to find the VM.
Can we move `getvm` method to `vmware.py` so that `vmware_guest_facts` or other modules could use it?

I have tested, and found that **_FindByInventoryPath_** does need the full path to find a folder in both my scenarios where VMs are nested like so.
/TestDCFolder/TestDC/TestCluster/TestFolder/
and
/TestDC/TestCluster/TestFolder/

In both cases, I needed to change searchpath to match the full path to the DC, then /vm/ and the actual folder.  So in the above instances it was.
/TestDCFolder/TestDC/vm/TestFolder/
and
/TestDC/vm/TestFolder/

comments.body: So to me cdrom is part of the hardware, so under the hardware parameter.

Then disk should also be moved under hardware... I've followed the same procedure as disk. Adding cdrom into hardware will cause a 3 level dict, which i think is a bit complicated for this. (same for network)
I would like to see `cdrom` as separate spec as it is now. Like @pdellaert said, it will complicated if we move it under hardware.

Ok, I am confused, about it being a 3rd level dict (and why that even matters) and it being complicated (why ?).

Even if it is under hardware it could be a separate spec, I don't see why that would matter.

To me putting everything as a top-level parameter is problematic, that's why we introduced the hardware parameter in the first place. The problem here is that if people add it the way they prefer, things will become very inconsistent (and I guess this is why we are having that discussion now, again).
